property.name: text
property.value: Coulomb's model of friction. A force is applied to mass 1. Mass 2 will move with it, unless it starts sliding. While sliding, kinetic friction causes mass 2 to accelerate.

property.name: text
property.value: Sinusoidal force on mass 1 pulls and pushes mass 2 due to friction. While the force is below the breakawayForce, mass 2 moves with mass 1. Mass 2 starts sliding on mass 1 whenever either an impulsive force arrives or the force exceeds the breakaway force. While mass 2 is sliding, the kinetic friction force on it is independent of the relative speed (Coulomb's law of friction), but it does depend on the direction mass 1 is moving. Mass 2 may be recaptured (stick to mass 1) if its velocity matches that of mass 1, the force on mass 1 does not exceed the breakawayForce, and there is no impulsive force on mass 1.

property.name: HTMLText
property.value:
Click on the TimedPlotter to see a plot of the velocities as a function of time. With these parameter values:
  • Near time 0.2, mass 2 breaks away and begins sliding.
  • Near time 0.7, the velocities match, but the input force is too high for capture.
  • Near time 0.8, mass 1 reverses direction, starting to move right instead of left. At that time, the velocity of mass 2 stops decreasing and starts increasing.
  • Near time 1.0, mass 1 is jolted left with an impulsive force, reversing direction, causing the velocity of mass 2 to stop increasing and start decreasing. Although the velocity of mass 1 crosses that of mass 2, no capture occurs.
  • Near time 1.8, the volocities match and the input force is small enough so that mass 2 is captured.
  • At time 2.0, an impulsive force on mass 1 causes mass 2 to start sliding.
  • Etc.

property.name: text
property.value: Both force inputs are assumed to be applied to mass 1 only.

property.name: text
property.value: Any impulsive force input causes a breakaway, so the force affects only mass 1. Mass 2 keeps the final velocity it had at the time of the impulsive force.

property.name: text
property.value: Capture events can occur when impulsive forces cause the volocity of mass 1 to cross the velocity of mass 2. But this should not lead to capture unless the final velocities are close enough. Also, numerical errors can lead to failures in capture, so we have a capture threshold.

property.name: text
property.value: While sliding, the force on mass 2 is kinectic friction, which is independent of the sliding velocity (Coulomb's law of friction), except for the polarity. The dependence on polarity is modeled using a modal model to ensure that the acceleration is piecewise continuous (using a signum function would not provide this assurance).

property.name: text
property.value: When the velocities match, mass 2 is recaptured and begins moving with mass 1. The capture event will trigger a mode change, unless there is simultaneously present an impulsive force.

property.name: text
property.value: Force on mass 2 is towards the right.

property.name: text
property.value: Force on mass 2 is towards the left.

property.name: text
property.value: Any non-zero impulsive force will cause a breakaway, so we can safely ignore this input here.
